Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Equilibria and Stability in Financial Markets
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of understanding the financial markets from the quantitative perspective is important not only for its intellectual merit, but also for its role in risk management or regulation. The equilibrium approach combines the time-tested economic insights with modern mathematical tools to achieve this goal. This project will use the equilibrium approach to further our grasp of so-called incomplete markets, i.e., the markets which--just like the real-world markets--have a limited ability to mitigate risk.

The investigator will study a number of questions centered around the notion of a stochastic equilibrium in incomplete continuous-time financial markets. The goals of the proposed research are two-fold. On the conceptual level, it aims to provide a general methodology for the specification of continuous-time asset-price models from the market primitives and to establish a new modelling framework for the analysis and better understanding of incomplete financial markets and their equilibrium dynamics. A novel concept of completeness constraint is introduced in order to capture the fruitful idea that market incompleteness can be interpreted as an exogenously-imposed constraint. On the technical level, it furnishes tools for the mathematical analysis of the framework described above, based on the existing and new stochastic-, convex- and functional-analytic and PDE-based methods. These tools are, then, used to establish the existence of equilibria and to study their properties. The mathematical core is the study of the notion of stability for the optimal solutions of stochastic control problems as functions of the modelling inputs. The obtained stability results can be interpreted in terms of the aggregate demand functions and used to grant existence of equilibrium markets with the help of the appropriate (classical and new) fixed-point theorems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focused on the investigation of the properties of financial markets that can be deduced from simple assumptions on the nature of its participants and the mechanisms that facilitate their interaction. Together with his undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral associates and faculty peers, the PI proposed a series of mathematical models of financial markets where a special emphasis was placed on interaction among the market participants, modeled as rational agents in the von Neumann-Morgensterm paradigm. Special attention has been paid to the structure of exogenously imposed constraints that limit the power  of the market to redistribute the inherent risk in a (Pareto) optimal manner. These constraints describe the nature of the real markets much better when compared to the unconstrained models. Unsurprisingly, they also lead to particularly severe mathematical difficulties. 


The PI and his collaborators identified several constraint structures which yield stable financial markets, and introduced novel mathematical techniques for their analysis. Ties to the theory of systems of backward stochastic differential equations have been introduced, and new existence theorems proved. Moreover, the project had broader impacts, beyond mathematics, in the fields of (financial) economics and risk management.The new models and the tools introduced to analyze them are projected to have an impact on policy in the areas of financial-market regulation and utilization.


In addition to its scientific facets, a large portion of the project's effort has been expended for various outreach, training and instructional activities. The PI advised a number of undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Texas at Austin, built several new undergraduate and graduate courses, organized and participated in multiple international conferences and hosted a number of internationally renowned experts.
